<h1 class="entry-title">
Sen. Elizabeth Warren On Black Women Maternal Mortality: 'Hold Health Systems Accountable For Protecting Black Moms'	</h1>
<div class="article-meta entry-meta">
<span class="byline"><span class="author vcard">By <a class="url fn n" href="https://www.essence.com/authors/sen-elizabeth-warren/">Sen. Elizabeth Warren</a></span></span> <span class="article-meta__sep entry-meta__sep">·</span>
<span class="posted-on"><a href="https://www.essence.com/feature/sen-elizabeth-warren-black-women-mortality-essence/" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date published" datetime="2019-04-30T08:00:54-04:00">April 30, 2019</time><time class="updated" datetime="2019-07-03T13:20:07-04:00">July 3, 2019</time></a></span> </div>
</div>
<div class="headline-deck">
In an exclusive op-ed for ESSENCE, Sen. Elizabeth Warren lays out her plan for improving maternal mortality in Black and Brown mothers.</div>
</header>
<div class="entry-content">

<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#" class="email"><svg class="svg-icon" width="24" height="24" aria-hidden="true" role="img" focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 24 15.84" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><path d="M0 0v15.84h24V0zm1.53 13.41v-11l6.33 5.5zM12 9.5l-9.22-8h18.43zm9.22 4.83H2.78L9 8.92l3 2.59 3-2.59zm-5.08-6.41l6.33-5.5v11z"></path></svg></a>

<p>I
was 21 when I found out I was pregnant. Like millions of women, I felt like I
was strapped in on a roller coaster that had just shot off. Joy. Terror.
Curiosity. And sometimes all three in the same minute.  </p>
<p>Unfortunately,
despite decades of progress, roughly <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/maternalinfanthealth/pregnancy-relatedmortality.htm">700
women</a> continue to die each year from pregnancy or delivery
complications in the United States, making it one of only thirteen countries
where maternal mortality rates have <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/11/magazine/black-mothers-babies-death-maternal-mortality.html">worsened</a> over the last 25 years. We
are facing a maternal mortality crisis in America. </p>
<p>And
for Black moms, particularly those living in rural areas, it’s an
epidemic.  </p>
<p>The data shows that Black women are <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/maternalinfanthealth/pregnancy-relatedmortality.htm">three to four times</a> more likely than white women to die from pregnancy or childbirth-related causes. This trend persists even after adjusting for income and education. One major reason? Racism. </p>
<p>In a detailed report, <em>ProPublica</em> <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/severe-complications-for-women-during-childbirth-are-skyrocketing-and-could-often-be-prevented">found</a> that the vast majority of maternal deaths are preventable, but decades of <a href="https://nwlc.org/blog/racism-in-health-care-for-black-women-who-become-pregnant-its-a-matter-of-life-and-death/">racism and discrimination</a> mean that, too often, doctors and nurses don’t hear Black women’s health issues the same way they hear them from other women.</p>
<p>These
are structural problems that require structural solutions, and as they have so
often in the past, Black women and activists are leading the way. <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/amazing-first-step-advocates-hail-congress-s-maternal-mortality-prevention-n948951">Widowers</a>,
mothers, and groups like the Black Mamas Matter Alliance, MomsRising, and the
March of Dimes are demanding concrete actions to reverse these deadly outcomes.
The <a href="https://safehealthcareforeverywoman.org/aim-supported-patient-safety-bundles/">Alliance
for Innovation on Maternal Health</a> is developing tools to save lives
and stamp out racial disparities. Legislators in Texas and California are <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2017/08/09/texas-maternal-death-shawn-thierry/">collecting
data</a> and <a href="https://www.npr.org/2018/07/29/632702896/to-keep-women-from-dying-in-childbirth-look-to-california">rolling
out new best practices</a>. <a href="https://www.wnyc.org/story/newark-doulas-take-disparate-birth-outcomes-black-mothers-head-first/">Cities
are
testing </a>whether covering doula services can help. </p>
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-56956630-1200x868.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-430958" srcset="https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-56956630-1200x868.jpg 1200w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-56956630-300x217.jpg 300w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-56956630-768x556.jpg 768w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-56956630-1568x1135.jpg 1568w" sizes="(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px" /></figure>
<p>In
Congress, Senator Kamala Harris <a href="https://www.glamour.com/story/senator-kamala-harris-bill-maternal-mortality-crisis">has a smart proposal </a>to address the
structural racism that puts Black women and their babies at risk and improve
care coordination. Senator Cory Booker has <a href="https://blog.everymothercounts.org/groundbreaking-legislation-introduced-to-improve-maternal-health-outcomes-in-the-u-s-d2bff8fda5e8">an important bill</a> to expand
Medicaid for moms. Congresswoman Lauren Underwood and Congresswoman Alma Adams
recently created the Black Maternal Health Caucus.   </p>
<p>I
support these efforts, and I have another idea: hold health systems accountable
for protecting black moms. </p>
<p>My
approach would apply to maternity care the lessons learned from successful
reforms — many <a href="https://www.commonwealthfund.org/publications/issue-briefs/2015/may/affordable-care-acts-payment-and-delivery-system-reforms">enabled by the Affordable Care Act</a> (ACA) — already
revolutionizing other types of procedures, like <a href="https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/9/4/17806348/obamacare-trump-bundled-payments-hospitals-research">joint replacements</a> or <a href="https://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20160725/NEWS/160729934/what-to-know-about-medicare-s-big-bundled-payment-expansion">cardiac care</a>. Rigorous evaluations
show these groundbreaking reforms <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/17/upshot/medicare-bundled-payments-cost-savings.html">hold immense promise</a>. And maternal
health has <a href="https://www.ajmc.com/contributor/katy-b-kozhimannil-phd-mpa/2016/05/a-bundle-of-joy-bundled-payments-for-maternity-care">already
been identified</a> as one of the ripest <a href="https://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20160813/MAGAZINE/308139965/bundles-of-joy-how-new-payment-models-for-maternal-care-could-deliver-lower-costs">areas</a> for expansion.</p>
<p>Rather
than paying separately for each visit or each procedure, these new models set
one price for an entire “episode” of care – and then hold health systems
accountable for the outcome. The data show that these so-called “bundled
payments” give health systems both greater incentives and greater control to improve
results.  </p>
<p>In
maternity care, health systems would have the flexibility to cover key services
— like prenatal and postpartum visits, hypertension and depression screenings,
and doula and lactation support —  based
on their effectiveness, not on their reimbursement rate. Outcomes could be
tracked for a significant length of time after birth, to ensure that women and
babies stay healthy during the postpartum period, and health systems could be
pushed toward greater workforce diversity so care teams look more like the
communities they serve. </p>
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-1200x800.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-430960" srcset="https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-1200x800.jpg 1200w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-300x200.jpg 300w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-768x512.jpg 768w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-900x600.jpg 900w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-450x300.jpg 450w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-90x60.jpg 90w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-1568x1045.jpg 1568w, https://www.essence.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/GettyImages-1068443012-272x182.jpg 272w" sizes="(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px" /></figure>
<p>If
health systems are able to coordinate their care and improve overall outcomes –
like raising survival rates, reducing complications, and narrowing the
mortality and morbidity gap between white women and women of color – they can earn
a bonus. If care doesn’t improve, they’ll be on the hook. But they won’t be
abandoned. Paying for better care means both rewarding excellent health systems
and identifying, investing in, and demanding more from struggling ones. </p>
<p>To
be sure, these reforms have limits. They cannot reach all of the underlying
causes of these inequities. They’re no substitute for the kind of guaranteed,
comprehensive access to general and reproductive health care for women long
before pregnancy. And they must be carefully designed and monitored to avoid
unintended consequences.  </p>
<p>Health
systems will need the resources to implement evidence-based best practices.
Determining what outcomes should be measured and how exactly an “episode” of
childbirth should be defined will require extensive input. Reforms must, for
example, account for the profile and volume of a hospital’s patient population,
recognize that different hospitals are set up to provide different levels of
maternity care, reward providers that take care of the most challenging
patients, and make room for non-hospital settings where many mothers receive
their care. Like the ACA reforms, these changes should be rigorously tested and
evaluated before being implemented nationwide. </p>
<p>In
all of these decisions, women who have given birth, experienced complications, and
lost babies – particularly women of color – and family members who have lost
loved ones should not just be at the table: <a href="https://www.wnyc.org/story/newark-doulas-take-disparate-birth-outcomes-black-mothers-head-first/">they
should be calling the shots.</a></p>
<p>By rewarding health systems that keep mothers healthier, pressing for broader adoption of best practices that we already know help Black and Brown moms, narrowing racial inequities – and yes, <a href="https://www.healthaffairs.org/doi/full/10.1377/hlthaff.2018.1013">holding both hospitals and care teams accountable</a> for preventable failures – we can save women’s lives and demand change. Black women shouldn’t have to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/11/magazine/black-mothers-babies-death-maternal-mortality.html">develop elaborate birth plans</a> or personally <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/2019/02/27/black-women-are-facing-childbirth-mortality-crisis-these-doulas-are-trying-help/?utm_term=.3cc3b6726d0a">shell out thousands of dollars</a> for extra eyes and ears at the hospital to ensure they survive the experience of childbirth. We’ve done enough observing and debating the effects of bias and racism in our health care system. It’s time to demand better outcomes.  </p>
<p><em>Elizabeth Warren is a United States Senator from Massachusetts (D) and 2020 Presidential candidate.</em></p>
<p><em>The above is an op-ed and not a political endorsement by ESSENCE.</em></p>
